content: We've talked a bit about the purpose and scope of #wg-traits
I've come to the opinion that (a) wg-traits should be a subteam of the lang team
to which the lang team generally delegates traits / type-checking / soundness issues
there is also an implementation side of things
we may want to organize a bit under that
I'm thinking about things like soundness issues and the like
this is something the lang team has talked about on and off, adjusting its structure
(cc @Josh Triplett, I think you agree with this, but I'd like to know :)
Yeah, I mean it's a bit interesting because we talk a lot about design (lang) and a lot about implementation (compiler)
I'm generally factoring up an RFC around this and related topics
it's going to take some work to grow and figure out membership
but I think it's an important thing for us to do :)
I'm trying to think, is there another wg (or wg-like team) that has such a heavy overlap between design and implementation?
Maybe nll wg?
NLL, yes, const generics
const generics is a project group, and it would definitely also fall under the general scope of what I'm taking about here
Ah, yeah, const eval
I think I would just include <-- EDIT: (I meant include const generics)
const eval too
I think a key difference is wg-traits covers a lot of different features under the "area" of trait solving
Thought I guess you can imagine that const eval has a lot of features
Definitely thought about this given the "Team Charters" section of https://blog.rust-lang.org/inside-rust/2021/05/04/core-team-update.html
const-eval is a bit different, but I think that reckoning and integrating the "formal semantics" for these things feels connected
I think ultimately we want to separate the impl from the design a bit more
/me thinks

@nikomatsakis I definitely agree with making it a subteam with that domain. I'm not yet sure exactly what process we would use for issues (somewhere on the spectrum from "consult" to "delegate"), but the general idea seems sound ( :grinning: ) to me.
Yeah, I'd probably expect it to depend on the question
As an example, I think that for implied bounds, I would expect the broader team to weigh in on questions like the semver
I think "advisory board" is probably the right metaphor
Really the same as deferring to a project group on the details, and delegating to them to come up with the options
Yeah, a cross between an advisory board and a project group sounds about right.
